benefits.title: Beneficial Effects of Saw Palmetto Fruit Extract on Urinary Symptoms in Japanese Female Subjects by a Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study
benefits.summary: Saw palmetto berry extract significantly reduces lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in adult women, including daytime frequency and nocturia.

benefits.title: Natural Hair Supplement: Friend or Foe? Saw Palmetto, a Systematic Review in Alopecia
benefits.summary: Supplements containing saw palmetto show positive effects on hair regrowth, with 60% improvement in overall hair quality, 27% improvement in total haircount, and increased hair density in 83.3% of patients.

benefits.title: Fatty Acid and Phytosterol Content of Commercial Saw Palmetto Supplements
benefits.summary: Liquid saw palmetto supplements contain the highest concentrations of fatty acids and phytosterols, potentially improving BPH and lower urinary tract symptoms.

benefits.title: Multiple doses of saw palmetto (Serenoa repens) did not alter cytochrome P450 2D6 and 3A4 activity in normal volunteers
benefits.summary: Saw palmetto extracts at generally recommended doses are unlikely to alter the disposition of coadministered medications primarily dependent on the CYP2D6 or CYP3A4 pathways for elimination.

benefits.title: Saw palmetto and lower urinary tract symptoms: What is the latest evidence?
benefits.summary: Saw palmetto may exert physiologic effects consistent with a beneficial clinical effect on the mechanisms of benign prostatic hyperplasia, but its precise clinical value for treating lower urinary tract symptoms remains undefined.

benefits.title: BPH: Combination saws off LUTS
benefits.summary: A mixture of saw palmetto extract, selenium, and lycopene in combination with tamsulosin was more effective in improving lower urinary tract symptoms in patients with moderate to severe BPH than either SeR–Se–Ly or tamsulosin alone.

benefits.title: Review: evidence is incomplete on the benefits and risks of commonly used herbal medicines
benefits.summary: Saw palmetto might reduce symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia in the short term, with rare and mild adverse effects.

benefits.title: Extravesical surgery benefits patients with unilateral vesicoureteral reflux
benefits.summary: Saw palmetto was no more effective than placebo in improving LUTS in men.

benefits.title: Date palm and saw palmetto seeds functional properties: antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial activities
benefits.summary: Saw palmetto seeds have strong antioxidant, anti-bacterial, and anti-fungal properties, making them beneficial for health.
benefits.journal: Journal of Food Measurement and Characterization

side effects.title: Saw Palmetto Berry as a Treatment for BPH.
side effects.summary: Occasional gastrointestinal upset is the only side effect reported for saw palmetto berry in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia.

side effects.title: Coagulopathy induced by saw palmetto: a case report.
side effects.summary: Some studies document adverse side effects of saw palmetto, including increased risk of bleeding.
side effects.journal: Boletin de la Asociacion Medica de Puerto Rico

side effects.title: Other Treatments for Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms Suggestive of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia: Self-management, Desmopressin and Phytotherapy
side effects.summary: Side effects of saw palmetto include well-tolerated lower leg edema, headache, and dizziness, but its therapeutic effects on LUTS/BPH are not consistent among clinical trials.

side effects.title: Protective Effect of Beta-Sitosterol against Ethanol Toxemia
side effects.summary: Beta-sitosterol, an ingredient in saw palmetto, can cause pancreatic damage in some cases.
side effects.journal: Journal of Undergraduate Research at Minnesota State University, Mankato

side effects.title: Acute pancreatitis with saw palmetto use: a case report
side effects.summary: A relationship between saw palmetto and the onset of acute pancreatitis is plausible, and prescribers and users should be alert to the possibility of such adverse reactions.

side effects.title: Multiple doses of saw palmetto (Serenoa repens) did not alter cytochrome P450 2D6 and 3A4 activity in normal volunteers
side effects.summary: Extracts of saw palmetto at generally recommended doses are unlikely to alter the disposition of coadministered medications primarily dependent on the CYP2D6 or CYP3A4 pathways for elimination.

side effects.title: Hepatotoxicity potential of saw palmetto (Serenoa repens) in rats.
side effects.summary: At the doses and time periods tested, saw palmetto did not produce any significant effect on the normal biological markers of liver toxicity.
side effects.journal: Phytomedicine : international journal of phytotherapy and phytopharmacology

side effects.title: Saw palmetto for benign prostatic hyperplasia.
side effects.summary: The incidence of side effects was similar in the two groups.
side effects.journal: The New England journal of medicine

side effects.title: A detailed safety assessment of a saw palmetto extract.
side effects.summary: No evidence for serious toxicity of saw palmetto was observed in this clinical trial, but these data do not rule out potential rare adverse effects.

side effects.title: Effect of saw palmetto extrac on bleeding volume in transurethral plasmakinetics resection of prostate
side effects.summary: SPE can reduce postoperative blood loss, bladder lavage fluid volume, and shorten the operation time in benign prostate hyperplasia patients undergoing TUPKRP.

dosage.title: Saw palmetto for benign prostatic hyperplasia.
dosage.summary: Saw palmetto extract (160 mg twice a day) did not improve symptoms or objective measures of benign prostatic hyperplasia in this study.
dosage.journal: The New England journal of medicine

dosage.title: A detailed safety assessment of a saw palmetto extract.
dosage.summary: The standardized extract of saw palmetto berry (160 mg twice daily) was used in this clinical trial without observing serious toxicity.

dosage.title: Hepatotoxicity potential of saw palmetto (Serenoa repens) in rats.
dosage.summary: At doses of 9.14 or 22.86 mg/kg/body wt./day, saw palmetto did not produce any significant effect on the normal biological markers of liver toxicity.
dosage.journal: Phytomedicine : international journal of phytotherapy and phytopharmacology

dosage.title: Fatty Acid and Phytosterol Content of Commercial Saw Palmetto Supplements
dosage.summary: Liquid saw palmetto supplements contain 908.5 mg/g of total fatty acids and 2.04 mg/g of phytosterols.

dosage.title: Acute liver damage due to Serenoa repens: a case report.
dosage.summary: The suggested oral dose of saw palmetto for benign prostatic hyperplasia is usually 320 mg day1 of dried extract of SP berries.

dosage.title: Effect study of saw palmetto extract in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia with overactive bladder
dosage.summary: Combination saw palmetto extract at 160mg once daily for 8 weeks has efficacy in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia patients with overactive bladder.

dosage.title: Effect of increasing doses of saw palmetto extract on lower urinary tract symptoms: a randomized trial.
dosage.summary: Increasing doses of saw palmetto fruit extract (320 mg/d) did not reduce lower urinary tract symptoms more than placebo.

dosage.title: The effect of increasing doses of saw palmetto fruit extract on serum prostate specific antigen: analysis of the CAMUS randomized trial.
dosage.summary: Higher doses of saw palmetto extract, such as 320 mg for the first 24 weeks, 640 mg for the next 24 weeks, and 960 mg for the last 24 weeks, do not affect serum prostate specific antigen levels more than placebo.

dosage.title: Saw Palmetto Therapy for Lower Urinary Tract Symptoms Associated with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia Assessment in Iraq
dosage.summary: Saw Palmetto cap (320 mg) and tamsulosin (0.4mg) were used in the study to treat lower urinary tract symptoms associated with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

dosage.title: Complementary and Alternative Medicine Interventions for BPH/LUTS
dosage.summary: In two definitive North American clinical trials, dosages of 320–960 mg of saw palmetto proved to work no better than placebo.
